creator: greg@netgraft.com
text:
I built a new Apache with mod_ssl etc built in,and on start up it failed on the
LoadModule lines from my old httpd.conf because the modules were already
built-in.  It then refused to start up, saying it was a syntax error.  Syntax
errors in the config file probably should abort startup - you never know what
the intent was.  But this was not a syntax error - e-mail me and I will refer
you to a dozen dictionaries.  It was a semantic error, and the semantic intent
was clear, and the fact that the intent was already achieved was also clear, so
it was totally inappropriate for Apache to refuse to start.  Are we serious
about enterprise stuff or do you just run kiddie servers?

creator: trawick@apache.org
text:
We will not be adding logic to properly support the existence of loadmodule
directives for modules that have been statically built into the server.

You'll need to change your config file as appropriate.

The mention of a "syntax" error is generic.  Certainly some errors which are
better classified as semantic are mislabeled.  However, I don't think this is a
source of confusion for the general user community.

creator: slive@apache.org
text:
Not to mention that if you build an apache without mod_so and then use 
LoadModule, that IS a syntax error.  Apache without mod_so has no knowledge
of any directive called LoadModule, and hence seeing that string in the
config file is a syntax error.

[In addition, if you really want help for this kind of issue you should

1. Tone down the attitude; and

2. Ask first in a user support forum before you bring things to the bug
database.]
